comments.html:
A decade later this is still an unsolved problem, with Network Prefix Translation (NPT) being the only somewhat-sane solution.

https://blog.ipspace.net/2011/12/ipv6-multihoming-without-nat-problem.html

CLNS (or "address per host") solves the local multihoming challenge (host attached to two interfaces) but not the global one (site attached to two providers). More in https://my.ipspace.net/bin/list?id=Net101#ADDR
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html: I have two home internet services, both provide IPv6, one does prefix delegation, the other does not. Tried running both at the same time, but got lots of strange connectivity issues, so I disabled one. Of course the firewall I use can do 464 or 646 but not NatPT. The whole multi-homed but not a BGP AS, still a problem. Time to bring back the blog posts on CLNS again, even though it's too late? lol
